column4: Question: Anybody have any recommendations on which channel is best for asking about really old network cards (ISA interface)?
wtf oO
i don't think ubuntu would run on pc's that still got an isa interface...
Well, Xubuntu 6.10 runs, just slowly.
well, if its recognized, where is the problem ?

I think there is more configuration to do, I just don't know what. The card gets an IRQ assigned after modprobe, so I assume it can work. But it doesn't come up with an IP address assignment or anything.
anything on ifconfig ?
I don't know. I will go find out.
Nope, ifconfig shows only a local loopback at 127.0.0.1
and ifconfig -a ?
ifconfig -a shows an eth0 device at IRQ10 with a real-looking HW Addr, but no IP address shown.
try ifup'ing it
OK... I'll go read the man page on that and give it a shot. I appreciate the pointers -- I rarely know how to start with these things, and #ubuntu always comes through with at least an orientation.

ifup seems straightforward enough, but running "ifup eth0" gives an error: "failed to open statefile /var/run/network/ifstate: Permission denied." Trying "sudo ifup -v eth0" returns "Ignoring unknown interface eth0=eth0".
Am I correct in thinking that the card was detected by modprobe? It wouldn't have an IRQ assignment if nothing was found, right?
well, it showing up in ifconfig at all is a good sign
well, try asigning an ip and netmask manually with "ifconfig eth0 address 1.1.1.1 netmask 1.1.1.1" and then "ifconfig eth0 up" (replace 1.1.1.1 with apropriate values)
OK, I'll give it a shot.
or ask someone else how to get the modprobe to work automatically on boot so ubuntu configures it for you
Is it possible to execute a modprobe in the middle of an install? It's a fresh install and I don't mind redoing it.
install of what ?
Install of Xubuntu 6.10.
it shouldn't matter
